questions.prompt: The rise time t_r of a first-order circuit with τ = 5ms is:
questions.explanation: t_r = 2.2τ = 2.2 × 5 = 11 ms. Rise time is from 10% to 90% of steady state.
e⁻³ = 0.050, so 1−0.05 = 95% complete. After 3τ, only 5% remains.

questions.prompt: The tangent rule states that the tangent at t₀:
options: Passes through x(∞) at t₀ + τ
questions.correctAnswer: Passes through x(∞) at t₀ + τ
questions.explanation: The tangent line from any point on the exponential extrapolates to the steady-state value exactly one time constant later. This is a graphical way to find τ.

questions.prompt: The inspection method needs which three quantities?
questions.explanation: These three numbers completely determine the exponential waveform. No differential equations needed — apply the general formula x(t) = x(∞) + [x(t₀)−x(∞)]e^(−t/τ).
τ < 0 makes e^(−t/τ) = e^(+t/|τ|), which grows without bound. The circuit is unstable — typically caused by positive feedback.

questions.prompt: The elapsed time from x = 2V to x = 8V when x(∞) = 10V and τ = 1ms is:
questions.explanation: Δt = τ·ln[(2−10)/(8−10)] = 1·ln(8/2) = ln(4) = 1.39 ms. Using the elapsed time formula with x(∞) = 10.

questions.prompt: The bandwidth-rise time product for a first-order system is approximately:
questions.explanation: BW × t_r ≈ 0.35. Since t_r = 2.2τ and f_3dB = 1/(2πτ), the product is 2.2/(2π) ≈ 0.35.

questions.prompt: For piecewise-constant inputs, the exponential formula is applied:
options: Segment by segment, chaining initial conditions
questions.correctAnswer: Segment by segment, chaining initial conditions
questions.explanation: Each segment gets its own x(t₀), x(∞), τ. The final value of one segment becomes the initial value of the next. τ stays the same if the circuit topology doesn't change.

questions.prompt: The substitution theorem guarantees that ALL branch quantities:
options: Follow the same τ in a first-order circuit
questions.correctAnswer: Follow the same τ in a first-order circuit
questions.explanation: Every voltage and current in a first-order circuit follows x(t) = x(∞)+[x(0)−x(∞)]e^(−t/τ) with the SAME τ. Only x(0) and x(∞) differ from branch to branch.
